node.title: More People Googling 'How To Buy Fake Vaccine Cards' As January 4 Mandate Deadline Nears
node.description: Searches for counterfeit cards have surged since the Occupational Safety and Health Administration announced the mandate deadline and details on November 4.

node.title: Merck and Pfizer COVID Pills Compared As Paxlovid Appears to Cut Deaths
node.description: Almost two years since the start of the pandemic, more drugs to treat COVID patients may be on their way.

node.title: China Criticizes Press Freedom Survey That Shows Journalists Want to Leave Hong Kong
node.description: Eighty-three of 99 participants said the journalism environment has "changed for the worse" after a law was adopted in response to pro-democracy protests.

node.title: Pfizer, Merck COVID Pills Could Be Key to Ending Pandemic
node.description: Barring a vaccination surge, oral antivirals could be America's next best bet in returning to normal because they could reduce strains on health care systems.

node.title: Idaho Man Dies of Rabies in State's First Fatal Case Since 1978
node.description: Although the man didn't think he had been bitten or scratched, he did come into close contact with an infected bat, authorities said.

node.title: Police Beg Judge Not to Release Man Arrested 3 Times in 24 Hours
node.description: Robert Avila was arrested for a third time nine hours after his second arrest and now an officer is using an arrest affidavit to ask a judge not to release him.

node.title: What to Cook This Weekend
node.description: Practicing for Thanksgiving always helps, and now is the time to start.

node.title: Ronnie Wilson, Founder of the Gap Band, Dies at 73
node.description: After beginning his career as a teenager, he joined with his two younger brothers to record R&B hits like “You Dropped a Bomb on Me” and “Outstanding.”

node.title: Those Loud and Polluting Leaf Blowers
node.description: Readers mostly excoriate and urge alternatives to what one calls “these obnoxious, deafening, exhaust-spewing machines.” Also: The metaverse; signs of concern.

node.title: Owner Says French Bulldog Choked on Dog Biscuit in Starbucks 'Puppuccino'
node.description: Megan Harrison said she was "absolutely disgusted" by Starbuck's response to her puppy's death after she was offered a £250 voucher as compensation.

node.title: Ex-Macron Aide Convicted of Assault and Posing as a Police Officer
node.description: The aide, Alexandre Benalla, who was fired in 2018 after videos emerged of him beating a man at a labor protest, was sentenced to serve a year of house arrest with electronic monitoring.

node.title: When Bad News About the Climate Is Good for Green Stocks
node.description: Markets respond when coverage of global warming spikes, new research suggests. But investors could become inured to the bleak state of climate change.

node.title: Bald Eagles Filmed Fighting in Minnesota Street: 'It's Just Crazy'
node.description: A police officer who responded to the scene said: "It's definitely one of the most memorable calls I've been on."

node.title: Virginia Loss Was Bad for Joe Biden, Could Be Even Worse for Donald Trump
node.description: Glenn Youngkin's winning campaign could be a sign that Trump-style politics can succeed without him.

node.title: With Predominantly White Jury Sworn In, Trial Begins in Shooting Death of Ahmaud Arbery
node.description: Greg McMichael, his adult son Travis McMichael, and their neighbor William "Roddie" Bryan are facing murder and other felony charges.

node.title: Google Temps Fought Loss of Pandemic Bonus. And Won.
node.description: When a Google staffing agency reneged on a promise to pay an attendance bonus, temps who are part of the company’s union organized and forced it to backtrack.

node.title: Remains in Colorado Are Believed to Be West German Hiker Missing Since 1983
node.description: Rudi Moder, who was described as an experienced winter mountaineer, disappeared nearly 40 years ago during a skiing trip in Rocky Mountain National Park.

node.title: Near-Daily Covid Tests, Sleeping in Classrooms: Life in Covid-Zero China
node.description: Residents in Ruili, in southwestern China, have been locked down four times in the past year as part of the country’s quest to eliminate the virus.

node.title: ‘Les Éternels’: les super-franchises redescendent sur Terre
node.description: Après “Nomadland", Oscar du Meilleur Film, la réalisatrice Chloé Zhao s’essaie au blockbuster avec le dernier-né des Marvel, un casting séduisant à l’appui.

node.title: How to Track Runners in the New York City Marathon.
node.description: Spectators can track runners online and on an app in real time on race day.

node.title: The Metaverse Takes Manhattan
node.description: NFT.NYC, a gathering for nonfungible token enthusiasts, offered a taste of a crypto-filled future.

node.title: A Body Donated for Science Was Dissected for a Paying Audience
node.description: The widow of David Saunders, 98, said she did not know the body of her husband, who died of Covid-19, would be taken apart at an Oregon hotel where audience members paid up to $500 to attend.

node.title: Vietnamese upset after video emerges of Salt Bae feeding gold-leaf steak to security minister
node.description: A video showing Salt Bae feeding a powerful Vietnamese official morsels of steak smothered in gold leaf at a luxury London restaurant sparks anger in the South-East Asian country, where the average person earns a few dollars a day.
